explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET - This is a macro that performs the table lookup (used as: OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., *token)). Macros are the most common place to hide compiler-specific extensions (GNU statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, token-pasting tricks, non-standard attributes). You must inspect its definition for any language extensions.

OS_impl_filehandle_table - The object passed into the macro. Its type or initializer may use extensions (attributes, special sections, or nonstandard initializers) that affect whether the code uses language extensions.

OS_impl_file_internal_record_t - The struct typedef for impl. Inspect its definition for nonstandard language features (bit-field types, anonymous structs/unions, compiler attributes, packed or aligned pragmas, anonymous bitfields or zero-width bitfields, flexible array members used in nonstandard ways).

OS_object_token_t - The token type (used as *token). Its typedef/definition could use extensions (e.g., nonstandard integer widths, compiler-specific attributes or opaque types).

OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS - Macro constant OR-ed into flags. Its definition could use nonstandard literal suffixes or macros that expand into extensions.

OS_DEBUG - Logging macro used here (variadic invocation). Logging macros often use GNU extensions (variadic macro extensions, ##__VA_ARGS__, statement-expressions, __builtin_* or __attribute__ usages). Inspect its definition for extensions.

true - The boolean literal used for impl->selectable = true; Verify how true/_Bool/bool is provided (stdbool.h or custom macro/enum). A nonstandard definition of true/bool would be a language extension.

fcntl, F_GETFL, F_SETFL - These POSIX symbols are used to read/set flags. Although standard on POSIX, inspect platform headers if concerned about compiler-specific definitions or macros that might use extensions in their implementations.

strerror, errno - Used in error reporting. errno is often a macro that may use thread-local storage or compiler intrinsics; strerror may be a macro or inline wrapper. Inspect their definitions if you must ensure no compiler extensions are being relied on in the visible callsites.

(Include the definitions of the above symbols/headers so the next analyzer can check whether any of them expand to or depend on compiler/language extensions.)
